title: Glimpses of Europe;
author: Johnson, Jesse
snippet: From this array it was easy to imagine, and we seemed to see, the front of " grim visaged war " in those rough and rugged .days. From there, still inside the fortress, we went to a room called Queen Mary's Room. This is the room where Mary Queen of Scots is said to have lived, and in a little communicating room, certainly not larger than a small hall bedroom in a Brooklyn house, we were told the Queen bore James VI.

title: The British isles,
author: Tomlinson, Everett T.
snippet: In the Crown Room we see the old Scottish Regalia. We go to the old Parliament Hall, and there stop for a few moments in Queen Mary's Room.

title: A Voyage round Great Britain; with short views of Aberdeen, Balmoral, ... Fécamp, Havre and Paris
author: Hargreaves, Thomas
snippet: In the old Palace yard is the crown room, in which is the regalia of Scotland, the insignia of Scottish royalty, consisting of a crown, a sceptre, a sword of state, and a lord treasurer's rod of office. Near to the Crown Room, but with a separate entrance from the square, is Queen Mary's Room. In this room James VI., the son of Queen Mary, was born.

title: Notes by the Way; or, what I saw in my rambles
author: Higginson, H. Talbot.
snippet: ten years before. Next to the Crown Room, having a separate entrance from the Square, is Queen Mary's Room, a small apartment on the ground floor, of irregular form, less than nine feet long. It was here James VI.

title: Notes of foreign travel.
author: Bates, James Hale
snippet: Adjoining this room, but reached by another entrance from the court, is Queen Mary's Room, where she gave birth to James VI., commemorated by the initials H. and M. and the date 1566 over the doorway. This room has its original ceiling, with the initials J. R. and M. R. wrought in the panels.

title: Over the Ocean; or, Sights and Scenes in Foreign Lands
author: Guild, Curtis.
snippet: One of the most interesting, as well as one of the oldest rooms, was a httle inegular-shaped apartment, known as Queen Mary's Room, being the room in which James VI. was bom, in 1566.

title: European days and ways,
author: Rusling, James Fowler
snippet: Here we alighted, and, crossing the ancient drawbridge and moat, passed under the old portcullis, and so into the castle proper. Here we were shown the Crown Room, containing the ancient Scottish regalia; Queen Mary's Room, in which James I of England was born in 1566; the old Parliament Hall, now a museum and armory; and St. Margaret's Chapel, the oldest building in Edinburgh, dating back to 1100, and with its rude doors and quaint little windows looking quite that old. In front of the chapel is a huge cannon, called "Mons Meg," formerly believed to have been cast at Mons in Belgium, but now ascribed to Scottish skill.

title: Crusading with Knights templar under the banners of Allegheny commandery, no. 35,
author: Semple, David W. [from old catalog]
snippet: In the Crown Room are deposited the regalia, the insignia of Scottish royalty, consisting of the crown, sceptre, sword of state, and Lord Treasurer's rod of office. Adjoining the Crown Room is Queen Mary's Room, where Queen Mary gave birth to James YI, in whom the crowns of England and Scotland were united, On the wall is the following inscription, surmounted by the Scottish arms :

title: Four years in the Old world;
author: Palmer, Phoebe

title: Notes of foreign travel.
author: Bates, James Hale
snippet: 52 The Crown Room and Queen Mary's Room in the Castle.

title: Here and there in the Home Land. England, Scotland and Ireland as seen by a Canadian. ... Profusely illustrated
author: Haight, Canniff.
snippet: The adjoining apartment is known as Queen Mary's Room, in which she gave birth to James VI., in whom the crowns of England and Scotland were united. The event is commemorated by the initials " H" and " M " and the date, 1566, over the doorway.

title: Benedict's wanderings, in Ireland, Scotland, Italy and Sicily ...
